newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel court rejects bedouin petition.
newsitem.headline: Israel court rejects bedouin petition.

text.p: Israel's High Court on Wednesday rejected a petition by bedouin Arabs it block their eviction from lands adjacent to a West Bank Jewish settlement, a court spokesman said.
"Their petition was rejected," spokesman Moshe Gorali told Reuters.

The Jahalin bedouin tribe had protested against Israel's decision to move them from their encampments near Maaleh Adumim settlement east of Jerusalem to a new location designated by the government they said was unfit for habitation.
"The court ruled the new location was fine," Gorali said.
The court decision clears the way for the eviction of the Jahalin tribe.
Human rights activists condemned the ruling.
"We absolutely condemn this ruling which amounts to ethnic cleansing without genocide," said Boudewijn Wegerif, a champion of the bedouins' struggle.
Peter Lerner, spokesman for Israel's occupation authority in the West Bank, has said the bedouins were squatting on state-owned land and would be moved to a new area fitted with public services.
Wegerif told Reuters the proposed site for the tribe's relocation was adjacent to a garbage dump and had only one pipe to carry water to the 50 families of the Jahalin tribe.
"There is a very real danger of infestation," he said. "We are seeing a once-proud tribe being reduced to slum residents through Israeli actions."
Lerner said the current bedouin camp was on land earmarked for the expansion of the Jewish settlement of Maaleh Adumim.
"The court decision is against peace," the Palestinian Center for the Study of Nonviolence said in a news release.
"The settlements expansion is leading not to peace but to potential violence from an increasingly dissatisfied Palestinian people," the release said.
